Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2008 06:44AM quinnie wrote: I have good news!! I am BRCA negative. I had a feeling it was going to be negative so wasn't a huge surprise. Unfortunately I have another relative who was recently diagnosed. There is still quite a bit of BC so the counselor feels we just have a strong familial tendency or it is not a gene that is yet identified. My 4 sisters were most relieved but will need to be watched closely. Thanks for all the positive energy from this web site. Hopefully many of you will have the same results.  Take Care, Quinnie
Posts.Title: BRCA test I_Run_For_Hope cdsouza

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 04:17AM quinnie wrote: I just had my genetic counseling and testing done this week. It was highly suggested by my oncologist due to family history. I have BC scattered throughout both parents families. I have 4 sisters and 2 of their doctors also felt I needed to have the test. The counseling was very helpful and I also researched on the internet before I made the decision. I have not decided what to do if i am positive but all my sisters will definately be tested. Another waiting game but certainly not as stressful as waiting for pathology reports. Reading this thread has also helped hearing what others are doing and how they feel. Take Care, Quinnie
Posts.Title: BRCA test I_Run_For_Hope cdsouza

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 06:55AM quinnie wrote: I just found this thread and are thrilled with such good news. Keep up the good work Cathy and hope and pray for continued recovery. Sorry you have had to go through so much. I don't visit the chat room often but try to always keep up with my old buddies I met when I was first diagnosed. I always enjoyed chatting with TerryO. You are lucky to have each other for support.  Fondly, Quinnie
Posts.Title: Prayers for TerryO's Cathy dreamwriter carol1949

Posts.Content: quinnie wrote: Just heard the final pathology report and I am estrogen/progesterone negative and therefore will not need tam. only radiation. Good news for me but I have read conflicting information that this type cancer can be harder to treat. Any information would be appreciated Dx 11/30/2007, DCIS, Right, 1cm, Stage 0, Grade 2, 0/0 nodes, ER-/PR- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hormone receptor negative with DCIS quinnie Shirlann

Posts.Content: May 16, 2008 05:51PM quinnie wrote: Hi to all the Feb. rad girls. I read this site everyday to keep up with all of you. I am so sorry so many of you have problems. TIA's, tamox. SE's, heart monitors, ports, injections etc. Fortunately my treatment is over. My skin has healed and since I am ER/PR negative I do not have to take tamox. My energy has returned and is back to normal. My last rad treatment was 8 weeks ago. I did develop a frozen shoulder that I am getting PT for. I am an Occupational Therapist so I am not sure how I let this happen. I stretched everyday but it got ahead of me and finally saw an Ortho who injected cortisone and recomended PT. It is quite painful but I have regained some ROM in the shoulder. I have a long way to go. I have no follow up with my rad onc. He was a jerk and said "don't need to see you anymore". My oncologist is wonderful and will follow me every 3 months for a couple years. I am having the BRCA genetic testing done next month since I am the 3rd generation of BC. I Just found out my 30 year old cousin was diagnosed with BC last month.I have recommended this web site for support as you all have given me much support over the past 5 months. Even though I don't write much, I continue to read daily and hope you all are doing better. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2008 06:55AM quinnie wrote: Hi Bluewillow, My rad. oncologist dismissed me after my last treatment. Said I didn't need to see him. I was relieved since he was a jerk. But my breast surgeon made it quite clear to wait 6 months after radiation before having a mamo. I am sure there are multiple things to consider when making the decision as to when to have the first mamo after radiation such as diagnosis, size, treatment, grade etc.It is interesting to see what others are doing. I am already a little nervous about the first mamo as I am still sore from the lumpectomy and radiation and was glad to hear yours wasn't too bad. When I do have the mamo I have an appointment with my breast surgeon immediately following and carry the film over to her office, so no wiating.I was very relieved to see that they routinely do this for those who have history of BC. Hopefully yours will be good. Take care, Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2008 09:53AM quinnie wrote: Hello to the Feb. Rad team: Candy-sorry you have to go through so much. My thoughts and prayers are with you. slbooch- People at work were asking me why I was late everyday. I told them it was because of my radiation treatments! I work in a health care setting so most are very concerned but are surprised I am so open and talking about it. The medical director has yet to say one word to me. She has ignored me for the past 3 months. I always feel better talking about it and welcome questions.
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 07:18PM quinnie wrote: Hi gals, I just finished week 4. I am also experiencing days of overwhelming fatigue and other days I am OK. Not sure why either. I am overall pink with areas of dermititis on my chest that itches. Over the counter cortisone didn't help so they gave me a prescription cortisone that has helped quite a bit. I am also VERY sore and achy in the area of treatment and down my arm to the elbow. Getting into position is getting much harder since my shoulder hurts so much. Have shooting pains also. All sounds bad but is actually better than I thought it would be. I am feeling more down though and need to keep a watch on that as I have had depression in the past. I am really anxious to be done with it and try to get my arm back in shape. Hope you are all doing well. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2008 07:12PM quinnie wrote: Feb. Rad girls, I am nearing the end!!!  Yea!!! 6 more to go. I do have redness and itching on the area of my chest that is exposed to sun. The remainder of the area is just real pink. The whole area is just very sensitive like raw nerve endings with occassional shooting pains. Overall I think I was very lucky compaired to what many of you have been through. Did I mention fatigue?   Yes, definately have that but is not something that is relieved by sleep so will just have to wait until it is over.  The techs and staff are great. I have never had to wait and they are so friendly and respectful. Have never had any blood work but the RAD ONC did say I will need a bone density test once this is over. I am 51 and have never had one so is probably a good thing to have anyway.  I did find aloe at Wallgreens and use it along with cortisone for the itching and it really has helped.  My Rad journey is almost over and I actually have mixed feelings. I feel while fighting the disease I am actually doing something about it. How do you all feel about this? Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2008 09:48AM quinnie wrote: Dawn,  Sending prayers to you and your family.  Quinnie
Posts.Title: Definely Crunch Time for Zarowny!!! hollyann BethNY

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 08:56AM quinnie wrote: Hi to the February Rad girls!! I too will start in Feb and would love the support of this thread. I have my consult next week but have learned so much from this site. I did find a great very soft cotton bra at Kohl's (warner). I can't imagine going braless. Age and nursing my 3 kids has not been kind to me!! Good luck to you all and keep in touch.   Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2008 11:05PM quinnie wrote: Had my CT scan to set up rads on Wed., simulation Fri and will begin rads on Monday Feb 4th. Just curious how everyone is doing. They used black markers and covered them up with tape (instead of tatoos), used the pillow form, and the advise they gave me was no shaving, no deodorant (can use chrystal), no lotions, wear loose cotton clothing and will give me the lotion that they use next week. The team was very helpful and explained every detail. The Radiologist encouraged me to continue working but to reduce the hours if possible as I should expect some fatigued. We will see. I will take it day to day and see how I feel.    Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 05:47PM quinnie wrote: Hi Feb. Rad team. Just completed my second treatment. I am amazed how different each site is and their different recommendations. Slbooch--I use crystal deodorant. I have used it for years and it is one they recommend to use during radiation. You can purchase it at any pharmacy like Wallgreens or Rite Aid. "Tom's of Maine" is a herbal deodorant they said we can use. They gave me "Radiagel" to use 3 times a day even on weekends as a preventative measure. I see the nurse 2 x week for a quick check-up, the rad onc 1 x week and will talk to a dietician tomorrow. They have been very kind and thoughtful through every step, explaining what they are doing, why, what the sounds mean etc. They seem to really sense that although this is routine to them it is very scarry to me. Hope you all are adjusting. Let me know how it is going.
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 06:53AM quinnie wrote: lionessdoe: I am using a gel they gave called radiagel and same thing, it has no friction and as my skin is starting to get warm it is has cooling effect also. I also have an aching feeling in my arm and not sure why. Mostly in the shoulder area and could be due to the position. Some advil takes care of it.
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2008 10:51AM quinnie wrote: 3 boys 4 me: I too have 3 boys!!! Ages 25, 22 and 19. I just finished treatment 15 and can see the actual field. Was surprized how large it is. Just started getting red the last few days but having some skin breakdown on my chest where it is exposed to the sun. I am tired but definately manageable. My treatment is a breeze compared to what you are going through. I had lumpectomy, re-excision, then 6 weeks of RADS. No tomox for me since I am ER-. So my journey is nothing compaired to others here, and will be done in a 6 month period. At least I hope so!!! One never knows, but I try to be positive. Take Care. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 09:17AM quinnie wrote: Hi everyone on the Feb. Rad schedule. I am half way through!!! The biggest problem is the pain in my shoulder. My shoulder started hurting soon after surgery and having to get into position daily only adds to the problem. Yesterday I couldn't get into position and they had to push down on my arm. Thought I was going to loose it. They appologized the whole time but what can they do. I plan to take advil before next treatment, and try to stretch before and see if that helps. I am definately red and only actually have skin irritation in the area that is exposed to sun. Of course fatigue has set in but is manageable. Hope you all are doing well out there in the Radiation thread. God Bless you all, Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2008 05:16PM - edited Feb 24, 2008 05:16PM by quinnie slbooch: Have you tried the crystal deodorant? I have been using that for years and it works for me. As far as fatigue, I noticed that around 3:00 I start to drag at work and that is not the norm for me. Just don't have any energy but can work through it. I am taking one day off work each week to do nothing but rest, and read and try to catch up on some things at home that I haven't been getting to.  My biggest problem is the area on my chest that has had sun exposure. I have developed dermatitis that is very itchy. MD told me to use hydrocortosine but it isn't working. Will ask him tomorrow what else I can use. It is driving me crazy not to scratch it!!! Overall I think I am doing very well compared to what other stories I have heard. Hope all of you are doing well. Keep in touch and post what you are doing through. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 07:02AM quinnie wrote:  Congrats to all who have finished their Rads. I have 4 more to go!!! Just getting more uncomfortable with everything. Hurts to wear a bra but also to go without. Anything seems to irritate that area. I only blistered on my chest wall where it is exposed to sun and the rest of the area is very pink and leathery. The shooting pains are increasing especially with the boosts. The fatigue has been overwhelming lately. I try to fight it thinking it is all in my head but it is best to give in and rest. I too feel like I have turned into a blob, not exercising and eating early Easter candy!! But all that said, I have had it easier than many of you. Hugs to all of you who have suffered though this. I too have a hard time looking in the mirror with 2 different size breasts and feeling guilty about it. SO many emotions that filter though my brain during this time. Thanks to all of you for your support during this time. Twirlgirl, Luv, Sue,mrsdeg, M38, darah58, luvmy2girls, slbooch, Tinamae, lionessdoe, 12954 and anyone else I missed. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 06:58AM quinnie wrote: Hi to the Feb Girls: I am finished with my treatments as of last Friday. The boosts were actually a breeze. I was very emotional at the center saying good bye to everyone. I made the department my famous poppy seed bread and by the time my 2 minute treatment was over, half of the bread was gone. This was a journey I thought I would never have to take and the support of this site has been such a blessing. I learned more from reading here than from anywhere else. I have also learned that going in with an open mind is the best attitude. We all respond differently to each step of the way in our Breast Cancer journey from the initial mamogram to the final treatment. Having a place to vent our emotions and concerns without anyone judging us was so helpful to me. Good luck to all of you ladies and I am sure I will continue to read this post often. Please continue to update as we have a special bond here at the Feb. Rad Team site. Quinnie
Posts.Title: Looking for a February Rad Team debbbyb twirlgirl

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2008 06:40AM quinnie wrote: Viv, I have been following and an soooo happy for your good news. I am glad you heard before the weekend so you can enjoy yourself. My first mamo post BC will be in October and not really looking forward to it, but I will try not to think about it before then. Of course we always have this site for support. You all ROCK. Quinnie
